etymologies: Middle English: from Old French microcosme or medieval Latin microcosmus, from Greek mikros kosmos ‘little world’

definitions: a community, place, or situation regarded as encapsulating in miniature the characteristic qualities or features of something much larger

examples.text: Berlin is a microcosm of Germany, in unity as in division

shortDefinitions: community, place, or situation regarded as encapsulating in miniature characteristics of something much larger

definitions: humankind regarded as the epitome of the universe

examples.text: the belief in correspondences between the Universe and Man—between microcosm and macrocosm

shortDefinitions: humankind regarded as representation in miniature of universe
